update.description:
This PR adds a new simulator metrics endpoint, which initially just keeps track of instance-hours used by each user/team.

As a separate pull request there will be a new middleware to reject requests if the max number of hours for the user/team was reached.
update.title: Initial simulator metrics

@chapulina please look at this . This is why I've hardcoded 000 in the tests. As I am creating an initial configuration as part of the startup. 
Do you have a different naming convention for initial resources created during startup?

content.raw: Looking good. I only have a comment about test coverage

content.raw: I think we can't be sure that the id for this resource will be 000, because the counter is not reset between tests. We can hold the value for this on a variable the moment we create the resource.
content.html: I think we can't be sure that the id for this resource will be 000, because the counter is not reset between tests. We can hold the value for this on a variable the moment we create the resource.

content.raw: Could you add some tests where the config is successfully updated? The test coverage report shows that the `updateMetricsConfig` function is not covered.
content.html: Could you add some tests where the config is successfully updated? The test coverage report shows that the updateMetricsConfig function is not covered.

content.raw:
Updated the PR with several changes based on the design conversation we had with @chapulina. 
This pull request adds:

- ability to have multiple (POST) metrics-configs resources. These configurations are used to reject launch instance requests when the maximum allowed hours is reached by the targetted identity. These configurations are "targetted", ie. they have a field "identity" that is used to target the instance-hours configuration to any specific user/team/role.

- updated the middleware/reject logic based on the discussion. 

- several new tests

@chapulina could you please take a look ? Thanks!
content.html:
Updated the PR with several changes based on the design conversation we had with @chapulina. This pull request adds:

  • ability to have multiple (POST) metrics-configs resources. These configurations are used to reject launch instance requests when the maximum allowed hours is reached by the targetted identity. These configurations are "targetted", ie. they have a field "identity" that is used to target the instance-hours configuration to any specific user/team/role.

  • updated the middleware/reject logic based on the discussion.

  • several new tests

@chapulina could you please take a look ? Thanks!

As a separate pull request there will be a new middleware to reject requests if the max number of hours for the user/team was reached.

content.raw: Based on your last comments, I'm thinking of having multiple records for the configuration. One per "team" (eg. "src-teamA") or per "competition" (eg. "SRC"). In the future it would be nice to be able to limit this by team (or organization). But currently it may be worth just limiting by "competition". What do you think ?
content.html: Based on your last comments, I'm thinking of having multiple records for the configuration. One per "team" (eg. "src-teamA") or per "competition" (eg. "SRC"). In the future it would be nice to be able to limit this by team (or organization). But currently it may be worth just limiting by "competition". What do you think ?

content.raw: Thanks for the clarification!
content.html: Thanks for the clarification!

content.raw: Oh, the config applies to all users? I thought it was user-specific. We might want to limit SRC users, but not SASC users for example.
content.html: Oh, the config applies to all users? I thought it was user-specific. We might want to limit SRC users, but not SASC users for example.

content.raw:
At the moment this isn't true. The simulator will have only the current username unless we share it with all of its identities (which might not be desired).

Also, if a user joins a team after launching the simulator, that new identity wouldn't be referenced.

These are all corner cases, I think it's ok for us to start with the simple case of a user in one team, and in the case of SRC, we will always share the simulator with the team.
content.html:
At the moment this isn't true. The simulator will have only the current username unless we share it with all of its identities (which might not be desired).

Also, if a user joins a team after launching the simulator, that new identity wouldn't be referenced.

These are all corner cases, I think it's ok for us to start with the simple case of a user in one team, and in the case of SRC, we will always share the simulator with the team.

content.raw: That sounds good to me, even though I also see value in an admin getting the statistics for all teams/users, for example. I'll leave it up to you.
content.html: That sounds good to me, even though I also see value in an admin getting the statistics for all teams/users, for example. I'll leave it up to you.

content.raw:
I'm assuming that whenever a simulator is launched by a user, the created simulator resource will include as part of its permissions , all the user identities. And thus, it will include the user's team identity.
Is this a correct assumption ?
content.html: I'm assuming that whenever a simulator is launched by a user, the created simulator resource will include as part of its permissions , all the user identities. And thus, it will include the user's team identity. Is this a correct assumption ?

content.raw: Yes, you're right. The parameter value could in fact be any identify. The returned result will include (summarized) all the simulators that contain that identity in their list of permissions.
content.html: Yes, you're right. The parameter value could in fact be any identify. The returned result will include (summarized) all the simulators that contain that identity in their list of permissions.

content.raw: Agreed!
content.html: Agreed!

content.raw: I didn't fully understand the question. The way it is now, there is just 1 config object/resource. The admin (or another user with write permissions) would be able to PUT to that API and update the values.
content.html: I didn't fully understand the question. The way it is now, there is just 1 config object/resource. The admin (or another user with write permissions) would be able to PUT to that API and update the values.

content.raw: I guess we could filter the final result to only show the current user' related metrics (or a specific team/group result based on the team parameter)
content.html: I guess we could filter the final result to only show the current user' related metrics (or a specific team/group result based on the team parameter)

content.raw:
Very good question. Let me try to share my reasoning here: 

- I saw simulators have a list of permissions. These permissions "usernames" usually map to individual users or groups/teams .

- At the same time, the request authorized user has a set of identities.

- I assumed there was an intersection of those sets (simulator permissions and user's identities) at some point. So, when the middleware requests the csgrants.userResources , all simulators which are accessible (read/readwrite) by the current user should be returned.

But you're right in your question/clarification. If somehow the user does not have any access to that simulator, then the time reported for that user would not include it. 
We can definitely change this, if needed. If we were to do that, then I guess we should query all the simulators for a given team/group  (independently of current user permissions). 
What do you think?
content.html:
Very good question. Let me try to share my reasoning here:

  • I saw simulators have a list of permissions. These permissions "usernames" usually map to individual users or groups/teams .

  • At the same time, the request authorized user has a set of identities.

  • I assumed there was an intersection of those sets (simulator permissions and user's identities) at some point. So, when the middleware requests the csgrants.userResources , all simulators which are accessible (read/readwrite) by the current user should be returned.

But you're right in your question/clarification. If somehow the user does not have any access to that simulator, then the time reported for that user would not include it. We can definitely change this, if needed. If we were to do that, then I guess we should query all the simulators for a given team/group (independently of current user permissions). What do you think?

content.raw: it is a configuration flag to enable/disable launch instances rejection based on the instance-hours max limit. Admins can be disable the "balance check" (globally).
content.html: it is a configuration flag to enable/disable launch instances rejection based on the instance-hours max limit. Admins can be disable the "balance check" (globally).

content.raw: Oh nice, we should start using more 403s instead of 401s everywhere
content.html: Oh nice, we should start using more 403s instead of 401s everywhere

content.html: How can the admin user update the config for other users?

content.raw: Just checking, what does `check_enabled`  do?
content.html: Just checking, what does check_enabled do?

content.html: oh ok, I just tried this with swagger and saw a lot of users in the result. I'm just trying to figure out if we're sharing private information from a user with another user.

content.html: Just a clarification, does this mean that if a team has (somehow) a simulator which this user doesn't have permissions to, the time reported here would be incomplete, right?

content.raw: How are teams being differentiated from users here? In fact, does this need to be only about teams, maybe it could be any identity.
content.html: How are teams being differentiated from users here? In fact, does this need to be only about teams, maybe it could be any identity.

content.raw: All tests have a maximum of 1 user being returned. In which situations would it return more than one user?
content.html: All tests have a maximum of 1 user being returned. In which situations would it return more than one user?
